{{Other uses}} [[File:Duck and Cover 1440 x 1080 01836081.webm|thumb|thumbtime=53|320px|The official 1951 [[United States civil defense]] film, ''[[Duck and Cover (film)|Duck and Cover]]''. Intended primarily for children, it portrays the act of ducking and covering by Bert the Turtle.]] "'''Duck and cover'''" is a method of personal protection against the [[Effects of nuclear explosions|effects of a nuclear explosion]]. Ducking and covering is useful at conferring a degree of protection to personnel situated outside the radius of the [[Nuclear weapon yield|nuclear fireball]] but still within sufficient range of the [[nuclear explosion]] that standing upright and uncovered is likely to cause serious injury or death. In the most [[literal and figurative language|literal]] interpretation, the focus of the maneuver is primarily on protective actions one can take during the first few crucial seconds-to-minutes after the event, while the film by the same name and a full encompassing of the advice, also caters to providing protection up to weeks after the event.
The countermeasure is intended as an alternative to the more effective [[A Day Called X|target/citywide emergency evacuation]] when these [[CRP-2B|crisis relocation programs]] would not be possible due to travel and time constraints. Maneuvers similar, but not identical, to ''Duck and Cover'' are also taught as the response to other sudden destructive events, the maneuvers that are advisable in an [[earthquake]] or [[tornado]], in the comparable situation where preventive [[emergency evacuation]] is similarly not an option, again, due to time constraints. In these analogously powerful events, ''Drop, Cover and Hold on'' likewise prevents injury or death if no other safety measures are taken.
As a [[countermeasure]] to the lethal effects of nuclear explosions, ''Duck and Cover'' is effective in both the event of a surprise nuclear attack,<ref group="note" name="external">Although at the time that the advice first began to reach a large audience, in 1951 with the ''Duck and Cover'' film, the advent of [[Warning system|early warning RADARs]], such as the [[Pinetree Line]] of the era, increasingly made a [[Pre-emptive nuclear strike|successful surprise attack]] far less likely; however, numerous [[window of vulnerability|windows of vulnerability]] still remain, such as [[nap of the earth]] flying and the [[Fractional Orbital Bombardment System]]</ref> and during a nuclear attack of which the [[Civil defense siren|public has received some warning]], which would [[four minute warning|likely be about a few minutes]] prior to the [[nuclear weapon]] arriving.
==Procedure==
===During a surprise nuclear attack=== {{quote|Dropping immediately and covering exposed skin provide[s] protection against blast and thermal effects ... Immediately drop facedown. A log, a large rock, or any depression in the earth's surface provides some protection. Close eyes. Protect exposed skin from heat by putting hands and arms under or near the body and keeping the helmet on. Remain facedown until the blast wave passes and debris stops falling. Stay calm, check for injury, check weapons and equipment damage, and prepare to continue the mission.|[[US Army]] [[field manual]] FM 3–4 Chapter 4.<ref name="FM">{{Cite book|title=Nuclear, Biological, Chemical Protection Field Manual (FM 3-4)|publisher=[[US Department of Defense]]|location=Washington, DC|chapter=Nuclear Protection|chapter-url=http://www.globalsecurity.org/wmd/library/policy/army/fm/3-4/Ch4.htm|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20130313223255/http://www.globalsecurity.org/wmd/library/policy/army/fm/3-4/Ch4.htm|dead-url=yes|archive-date=13 March 2013|publication-date=21 February 1996}}</ref>}}
Immediately after one sees the [[Bhangmeter#Description|first flash]] of intense heat and light of the developing nuclear fireball, one should stop, get under some cover and drop/duck to the ground. There, one should assume a [[Prone position|prone-like position]], lying face-down, and to afford protection against the [[Bhangmeter#Description|continuing heat of the explosion]] further cover exposed skin and the back of one's head with one's clothes; or, if no excess cover or cloth is available, one should cover the back of one's head and neck with one's hands.
Similar instructions, as presented in the ''[[Duck and Cover (film)|Duck and Cover]] '' film, are contained in the British 1964 [[public information film]] ''[[Civil Defence Information Bulletin]] No. 5''<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=PgqhaZmPFRg|title=Civil Defence Bulletin – No. 5|publisher=[[YouTube]]|date=25 December 2006|accessdate=11 March 2013|type=video}}</ref> and in the 1980s ''[[Protect and Survive]]'' public information [[Film series|series]].<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=m6U9T3R3EQg&t=28m27s|title=''Protect and Survive: Action After Warnings'' 28:27–28:50 (part 10)|type=video|series=10|publisher=[[YouTube]]|publication-date=9 December 2012|accessdate=15 April 2015}}</ref> Children in the [[Soviet Union]] likewise received almost identical classes on countermeasures, according to ''Inside the Kremlin's Cold War'' authors [[Lionel Gelber Prize|Zubok and Pleshakov]].<ref>{{Cite book|url=https://books.google.com/?id=nHFCKmo2PH8C&pg=PA122&lpg=PA122&dq=Broken-Backed%20War#v=snippet&q=inkwell&f=false|title=One Nation Underground: The Fallout Shelter in American Culture|first=Kenneth D.|last=Rose|date=1 May 2004|publisher=NYU Press|via=Google Books|isbn=9780814775233}}</ref>
In U.S. Army training, soldiers are taught to fall down immediately and cover their face and hands in much the same way as is described above.<ref name="FM" />
In the classroom scene of the [[Duck and Cover (film)|film]], the rapid employment of [[school desk]]s, as an improvised shelter following the awareness of the initial light flash, is a countermeasure primarily to offer protection from potential ballistic window glass [[lacerations]] when the slower moving blast wave arrived. However, in higher [[effects of nuclear weapons|blast pressure zones]], where partial-to-total [[building collapse]] may occur, it would also serve a similar role to that borne out from experience in [[urban search and rescue]], where voids under the debris of collapsed buildings are common places for survivors to be found. More rigid examples of void-forming-tables to shelter under include the "[[Air-raid shelter#Morrison shelter|Morrison indoor shelter]]", which was widely distributed by the millions in Britain as a protective measure against [[building collapse]], brought about by blast pressures generated during the [[Strategic bombing|conventional bombing]] of cities in [[World War II]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.rafmuseum.org.uk/research/online-exhibitions/history-of-the-battle-of-britain/air-raid-shelter-protection.aspx|title=Air Raid Shelter Protection - History of the Battle of Britain - Exhibitions & Displays - Research - RAF Museum|publisher=}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://spartacus-educational.com/2WWmorrisonshelter.htm|title=Morrison Shelters|publisher=}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://mashable.com/2015/07/24/wwii-backyard-bunkers/|title=How families lived in their WWII backyard bomb bunkers|first=Alex|last=Arbuckle|publisher=}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.military-history.org/articles/air-raid-shelters.htm|title=Air Raid Shelters: A short history of British air-raid shelters WW1 and WW2|date=1 October 2010|publisher=}}</ref><ref group=note>The building in which the table/Morrison shelter is situated was advised to be as free from combustible materials as possible, as the potential of a fire in the debris, post-collapse, would be fatal to those sheltering inside.</ref>
====When warning is given==== Under the conditions where some warning is given, one is advised to find the nearest [[bomb shelter]], or if one could not be found, any well-built building to stay and [[shelter in place]]. Sheltering is, as depicted in the film, also the final phase of the "duck and cover" countermeasure in the surprise attack scenario.
===Cursory analysis=== The "duck and cover" countermeasure could save thousands. This is because people, being naturally inquisitive, would instead run to windows to try to locate the source of the immensely bright flash generated at the instant of the explosion. During this time, unbeknownst to them, the slower moving [[blast wave]],<ref name="ReferenceB">{{cite web|url=http://www.acq.osd.mil/ncbdp/nm/nm_book_5_11/appendix_F.htm |title=The Nuclear Matters Handbook |accessdate=2013-11-30 |year=1991 |publisher=[[Assistant Secretary of Defense for Nuclear, Chemical, and Biological Defense Programs]] |quote=""Initially, this blast wave moves at several times the speed of sound, but it quickly slows to a point at which the leading edge of the blast wave is traveling at the speed of sound, and it continues at this speed as it moves farther away from ground zero" |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130302091606/http://www.acq.osd.mil/ncbdp/nm/nm_book_5_11/appendix_F.htm |archivedate=2013-03-02 |df= }}</ref><ref name="ocw.nd.edu">{{cite web|url=http://ocw.nd.edu/physics/nuclear-warfare/notes/lecture-14 |title=Nuclear Warfare Lecture 14 by Professor Grant J. Matthews of University of Notre Dame OpenCourseWare. Mechanical Shock velocity equation |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20131219010502/http://ocw.nd.edu/physics/nuclear-warfare/notes/lecture-14 |archivedate=December 19, 2013 }}</ref> would be rapidly advancing toward their position, only to arrive and cause the window glass to implode, shredding onlookers.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://goodnewsnuke.com/|title=The Good News About Nuclear Destruction|quote=...most can save themselves by immediately employing the 'Duck & Cover' tactic, rather than just allowing an impulsive rush to the nearest windows to see what that 'bright flash' was across town, just-in-time to be shredded by the glass imploding inward from that delayed shock wave blast.|last=Conner|first=Shane|website=KI4U|publisher=KI4U, Inc.|accessdate=15 April 2015}}</ref> In the testimony of Dr. Hiroshi Sawachika, although he was sufficiently far away from the [[Hiroshima bomb]] himself and was not behind a [[Flat glass|pane of window glass]] when the blast wave arrived, those in his company who were had serious [[blast injury]] wounds, with broken glass and pieces of wood stuck into them.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://history.hanover.edu/courses/excerpts/111hiroshima.html|title=Hiroshima Survivors' Testimony – Testimony of Hiroshi Sawachika, 1986|accessdate=15 April 2015|publisher=[[Hanover College]] History Department|last=Sawachika|first=Hiroshi}}</ref>
===During earthquakes and tornadoes=== Similar advice to "duck and cover" is given in many situations where structural destabilization or flying debris may be expected, such as during an [[earthquake]] or [[tornado]]. At a sufficient distance from a [[nuclear explosion]], the [[blast wave]] produces similar results to these natural phenomena, so similar countermeasures are taken. In areas where earthquakes are common, a countermeasure known as "Drop, Cover, and Hold On!" is practiced.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.shakeout.org/dropcoverholdon/|title=Great ShakeOut Earthquake Drills - Drop, Cover, and Hold On|accessdate=15 April 2015|website=ShakeOut|publisher=Southern California Earthquake Center}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.earthquakecountry.info/dropcoverholdon/|title=How to Protect Yourself During an Earthquake... Drop, Cover, and Hold On!|accessdate=15 April 2015|website=Earthquake Country Alliance|publisher=Earthquake Country Alliance}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.cusec.org/earthquake-safety/drop-cover-a-hold.html|title=Drop, Cover, & Hold|accessdate=15 April 2015|website=CUSEC|publisher=Central United States Earthquake Consortium|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150417000807/http://www.cusec.org/earthquake-safety/drop-cover-a-hold.html|archivedate=17 April 2015|df=}}</ref> Likewise, in tornado-prone areas of the United States, especially those within [[Tornado Alley]], [[Tornado preparedness|tornado drills]] involve teaching children to move closer to the floor and to cover the backs of their heads to prevent injury from flying debris.<ref name="tornado">{{cite web|url=http://www.floridadisaster.org/hwa03/drill.htm |title=Florida Disaster |publisher=Wayback.archive.org |date=2007-02-05 |accessdate=2013-03-11 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20070205185900/http://www.floridadisaster.org/hwa03/drill.htm |archivedate=February 5, 2007 }}</ref><ref name="Plano">{{cite web |url=http://www.pisd.edu/about.us/safety/disaster.policy.shtml |title=Plano, Texas ISD |publisher=Pisd.edu |date= |accessdate=2013-03-11 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130514044534/http://pisd.edu/about.us/safety/disaster.policy.shtml |archivedate=2013-05-14 |df= }}</ref> Some US states also practice annual emergency tornado drills.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.vaemergency.gov/readyvirginia/stay-informed/tornado/conductdrill|title=Tornado Drill|accessdate=15 April 2015|website=VA Emergency|publisher=Virginia Department of Emergency Management}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.scemd.org/component/content/article/21-home-page/public-information/166-south-carolina-severe-weather-awareness-week|title=South Carolina Severe Weather Awareness Week|accessdate=15 April 2015|website=SCEMD|publisher=South Carolina Emergency Management Division}}</ref>
== History == The dangers of viewing explosions behind window glass were known of before the [[Atomic Age]] began, being a common source of injury and death from [[Largest artificial non-nuclear explosions|large chemical explosions]]. The [[Halifax Explosion]] of 1917, an ammunition ship exploding with the energy of roughly 2.9 kilotons of [[Trinitrotoluene|TNT]],<ref name="Ruffman 1994, p.276">Ruffman, Alan and Howell, Colin D. (edited by). ''Ground Zero: A Reassessment of the 1917 Explosion in Halifax Harbour'' (1994, Nimbus Publishing), p.276.</ref> injured the eyes and faces of hundreds of people who stayed behind and looked out of their windows after seeing a bright flash, with 200 blinded by broken glass when the slower moving blast arrived.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20121224172332/http://www.engr.psu.edu/cde/Short/MPS_course/newpage/Exp-Dam-Ass-1.pdf|title=Wayback Machine|date=24 December 2012|publisher=}}</ref> Every window in the city of [[Halifax, Nova Scotia]], was shattered in this catastrophe of human error.<ref name="Chryssa N 1917">{{cite journal |last1=McAlister |first1=Chryssa N. |last2=Murray |first2=T. Jock |last3=Lakosha |first3=Hesham |last4=Maxner |first4=Charles E. |title=The Halifax disaster (1917): eye injuries and their care |journal=British Journal of Ophthalmology |date=June 2007 |volume=91 |number=6 |pages=832–5 |doi=10.1136/bjo.2006.113878 |pmc=1955605 |pmid=17510478}}</ref>
In the Record of the "Nagasaki A-bomb War Disaster",<ref>http://www.gensuikin.org/english/photo.html PHOTOGRAPHS OF HIROSHIMA AND NAGASAKI</ref> those close to the [[hypocenter]] (Matsuyama township), were described as all having been killed, with the exception of "a child who was in an [[air-raid shelter]]." A little further away, Professor Seiki of Nagasaki Medical School Hospital was building an air-raid dugout 400 m from the hypocenter of the detonation and survived.<ref name="nukefallout.com">{{cite web|url=http://www.nukefallout.com/nagasaki.html|title=The Atomic Bombing of Nagasaki|publisher=}}</ref> Chimoto-san, who was atop a distant hill that creates the [[valley]] in which Nagasaki is situated, performed the similar "[[wikt:hit the deck|hit the deck]]" maneuver upon seeing the bomb drop, which was notably ''prior'' to the detonation. However despite having these few seconds of relatively unique warning, he did not stay on the ground for long enough after the ''flash'' subsided, and received some translational injuries due to prematurely standing-up again, at which point the slower moving blast wave swept past him and carried him with it for a few meters.<ref name="nukefallout.com"/>
According to the 1946 book ''[[Hiroshima (book)|Hiroshima]]'' and other books which cover both bombings,<ref name="Robert Trumbull pg 25,28">{{cite book|title = Nine Who Survived Hiroshima and Nagasaki: Personal Experiences of Nine Men Who Lived through both Atomic Bombings |date = January 1, 1957|first = Robert |last = Trumbull|pages =25,28,61,101,109,119}}</ref> in the days between the [[atomic bombings of Hiroshima and Nagasaki]], some survivors of the first bombing went to Nagasaki and taught others about ducking after the atomic ''flash'' and informed them about the particularly dangerous threat of imploding window glass.<ref>[https://web.archive.org/web/20161229163919/https://ke.army.mil/bordeninstitute/published_volumes/nuclearwarfare/chapter9/chapter9.pdf PSYCHOLOGICAL FACTORS IN NUCLEAR WARFARE Borden Institute pg 185]</ref> As a result of this and other factors, far fewer died in the initial blast at [[Nagasaki]] as compared to those who were not taught to duck and cover. The general population however was not warned of the heat or blast danger following an atomic flash, due to the new and unknown nature of the [[Nuclear weapon|atomic bomb]]. Many people in Hiroshima and Nagasaki died while searching the skies, curious to locate the source of the brilliant flash.<ref name="Robert Trumbull pg 25,28"/>
When people are indoors, running to windows to investigate the source of bright flashes in the sky still remains a common and natural response to experiencing a bright flash. Thus, although the advice to duck and cover is over half a century old, ballistic glass [[laceration]]s caused the majority of the 1000 human injuries following the [[Chelyabinsk meteor]] [[air burst]] of February 15, 2013.<ref name="Heintz">{{cite web |last1=Heintz |first1=Jim|last2 = Isachenkov|first2 = Vladimir|url=http://www.canada.com/news/Meteor+explodes+over+Russia+Ural+Mountains+injured+shock+wave+blasts+windows/7968297/story.html |title=Meteor explodes over Russia's Ural Mountains; 1,100 injured as shock wave blasts out windows| quote = Emergency Situations Ministry spokesman Vladimir Purgin said many of the injured were cut as they flocked to windows to see what caused the intense flash of light, which momentarily was brighter than the sun |publisher=Canada.com |date=2013-02-15 |accessdate= |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130221012916/http://www.canada.com/news/Meteor+explodes+over+Russia+Ural+Mountains+injured+shock+wave+blasts+windows/7968297/story.html |archivedate=2013-02-21 |df= }}</ref> This response was also observed among people in the vicinity of Hiroshima and Nagasaki.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.ki4u.com/goodnews.htm|title=The Good News About Nuclear Destruction|quote=...most can save themselves by immediately employing the 'Duck & Cover' tactic, rather than just allowing an impulsive rush to the nearest windows to see what that 'bright flash' was across town, just-in-time to be shredded by the glass imploding inward from that delayed shock wave blast.|last=Conner|first=Shane|website=KI4U|publisher=KI4U, Inc.|accessdate=15 April 2015}}</ref>
==Background==
[[Image:Bert2.png|left|frame|A ''[[Duck and Cover (film)|Duck and Cover]]'' poster, featuring Bert the Turtle]] The United States' monopoly on [[nuclear weapon]]s was broken by the [[Soviet Union]] in 1949 when it tested its first nuclear explosive, the [[RDS-1]]. With this, many in the [[Federal government of the United States|US Government]], as well as many citizens, perceived that the United States was more vulnerable than it had ever been before. In 1950, during the first big Civil Defense push of the [[Cold War]]—and coinciding with the ''Alert America!'' initiative to educate Americans on nuclear preparedness,<ref>{{cite web |url=http://conelrad.com/books/folio.php?id=P382|title=ALERT AMERICA!|accessdate=15 April 2015|website=CONELRAD|publisher=CONELRAD.com}}</ref> the adult-orientated [[Survival Under Atomic Attack]] was published. It contains "duck and cover" or more accurately, cover and then duck advice without using those specific terms in its ''Six Survival Secrets For Atomic Attacks'' section. ''1. Try to Get Shielded 2. Drop Flat on Ground or Floor 3. Bury Your Face in Your Arms ("crook of your elbow")''.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://archive.org/details/survivalunderato00bost|title=Survival under atomic attack|first=|last=Boston (Mass. Civil Defense Dept|date=1 January 1951|publisher=|via=Internet Archive}}</ref> The child-oriented film ''[[Duck and Cover (film)|Duck and Cover]]'' was produced a year later by the [[Federal Civil Defense Authority|Federal Civil Defense Administration]] in 1951. [[Image:SurvivalUnderAtomicAttack.jpg|right|thumb|250px|The adult-orientated ''[[Survival Under Atomic Attack]]'' issued in 1950, pre-dated the release of ''Duck and Cover'' in 1951-52. The booklet was accompanied by a companion film by the same name.<ref>[https://archive.org/details/0838_Survival_Under_Atomic_Attack_E01425_11_23_59_18 Survival Under Atomic Attack 1951 ''film'']</ref>]] "Duck and cover" exercises quickly became a part of [[Civil Defense]] drills that every US citizen, from children to the elderly,{{dubious|date=August 2015}} was encouraged to practice{{citation needed|date=August 2015}} so that they could be ready in the event of [[Nuclear warfare|nuclear war]].
Education efforts on the effects of nuclear weapons proceeded with stops-and-starts in the US due to competing alternatives. In a once classified, 1950s era, US [[Military simulation|war game]] that looked at varying levels of war escalation, warning and pre-emptive attacks in the late 1950s early 1960s, it was estimated that approximately 27 million US citizens would have been saved with civil defense education.<ref name="nsarchive.gwu.edu">{{cite web|url=http://nsarchive.gwu.edu/nukevault/ebb480/docs/doc+10A+1963.pdf|title=National Security Archive - 30+ Years of Freedom of Information Action|website=nsarchive.gwu.edu}}</ref> At the time however the cost of a full-scale civil defense program was regarded as lesser in effectiveness, in [[cost-benefit analysis]] than a [[ballistic missile defense]] ([[Nike Zeus]]) system, and as the Soviet adversary was believed to be rapidly increasing their [[nuclear stockpile]], the [[efficacy]] of both would begin to enter a [[diminishing returns]] trend.<ref name="nsarchive.gwu.edu"/> When more became known about the cost and limitations of the [[Nike Zeus]] system, in the early 1960s the [[United States Secretary of Defense|head of the department of defense]] under president [[John F. Kennedy]], [[Robert McNamara]], determined the ineffectiveness of the Nike-Zeus system, especially in its [[benefit-cost ratio]] compared to other options. For instance, [[fallout shelter]]s would save more Americans for far less money.{{sfn|Yanarella|2010|p=87}}
==Efficacy during a nuclear explosion== [[File:Operation Castle - Nectar - Detonation.ogv|thumb|right|1954 test shot ''Nectar'' of [[Operation Castle]] produced a yield of 1.69 [[TNT equivalent|megatons]] and was conducted off the coast of [[Elugelab|Teiter]] island. Note the distinctive near instantaneous ''[[Bhangmeter#Description|double flash]]'', with the second appearing brighter than the sun,<ref>{{cite web|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20170825003209/https://nsarchive2.gwu.edu//NSAEBB/NSAEBB190/02.pdf|title=Wayback Machine|date=25 August 2017|publisher=}}</ref> and the [[blast wave]] slowly, by comparison, spreading out turning the calm ocean water a [[Light scattering|frothy white]] when it arrives. The maximum average [[nuclear fireball]] radius is approximately {{convert|1.4|to|1.6|km|abbr=on}}.<ref name="Walker">{{cite web | last=Walker | first=John | authorlink=John Walker (programmer) | title=Nuclear Bomb Effects Computer | publisher=Fourmilab | date=June 2005 | accessdate=2009-11-22 | url=http://www.fourmilab.ch/cgi-bin/Bombcalc?yield=1690&yunit=1&range=5&runit=0.62137119&rotate=310&imsize=800 }}</ref><ref>{{cite web | last=Walker | first=John | authorlink=John Walker (programmer) | title=Nuclear Bomb Effects Computer Revised Edition 1962, Based on Data from The Effects of Nuclear Weapons, Revised Edition "''The maximum fireball radius presented on the computer is an average between that for air and surface bursts. Thus, the fireball radius for a surface burst is 13 percent larger than that indicated and for an air burst, 13 percent smaller''." | publisher=Fourmilab | date=June 2005 | accessdate=2009-11-22 | url=http://www.fourmilab.ch/bombcalc/instructions.html}}</ref> The outdoor blast and [[flash burn]] [[LD50]]s would be around 8 and 12 km respectively.<ref name="Walker"/><ref name="Mock up">{{cite web|url = https://www.remm.nlm.gov/radiationlethality.htm|title = Size of the Incident and Potential Affected Areas|website = REMM: Radiation Emergency Medical Management|publisher = U.S. Department of Health & Human Services|date = 12 January 2016}}</ref> This assumes personnel did not take any prompt countermeasures, instead standing still, absorbing the entire light energy emitted over the ≈20 seconds of emission.]] Within a considerable radius from the surface of the [[nuclear fireball]], 0–3 [[kilometer]]s—[[Effects of nuclear explosions|largely depending on the explosion's height, yield and position of personnel]]—ducking and covering would offer negligible protection against the intense heat, blast and prompt [[ionizing radiation]] following a nuclear explosion. Beyond that range, however, many lives would be saved by following the simple advice,<ref name="The Nuclear Matters Handbook">{{cite web|url=http://www.acq.osd.mil/ncbdp/nm/nm_book_5_11/appendix_F.htm |title=The Nuclear Matters Handbook |accessdate=2013-11-30 |year=1991 |publisher=[[Assistant Secretary of Defense for Nuclear, Chemical, and Biological Defense Programs]] |quote="Individuals who sense a blinding white flash and intense heat coming from one direction should immediately fall to the ground and cover their heads with their arms. This provides the highest probability that the air blast will pass overhead without moving them laterally and that debris in the blast wave will not cause impact or puncture injuries. Exposed individuals who are very close to the detonation have no chance of survival. At distances at which a wood frame building can survive, however, exposed individuals significantly increase their chance of survival if they are on the ground when the blast wave arrives and if they remain on the ground until after the negative phase blast wave has moved back toward ground zero" |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130302091606/http://www.acq.osd.mil/ncbdp/nm/nm_book_5_11/appendix_F.htm |archivedate=2013-03-02 |df= }}</ref> especially since at that range the main hazard is not from [[ionizing radiation]] but from blast injuries and sustaining thermal ''flash'' burns to unprotected skin.<ref name="Mock up"/><ref name="johnstonsarchive1">{{cite web|url=http://www.johnstonsarchive.net/nuclear/nukgr1.gif |title=Range of weapons effects |publisher=Johnstonsarchive.net |accessdate=2013-11-30}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.webofstories.com/play/54981?o=R |title=Little Boy on Hiroshima |publisher=[[Web of Stories]] |accessdate=2013-11-30 |type=video |last=Christy |first=Robert F. |authorlink=Robert F. Christy}} Weapon designer Robert Christy discussing scaling laws, that is, how injuries from ionizing radiation do not scale in lock step with the range of thermal flash injuries, especially as higher and higher yield nuclear weapons are used.</ref><ref name = negligible>{{cite web|url = http://www3.nd.edu/~nsl/Lectures/phys205/pdf/Nuclear_Warfare_9.pdf |title = Nuclear Warfare Lecture 9 |first = Grant J. |last =Matthews |publisher = University of Notre Dame OpenCourseWare|page = 3}} ''negligible''. Meaning that if one were close enough to get a harmful dose of radiation from a generic 1 megaton weapon, one would very likely die from blast effects alone at that proximity.</ref> Furthermore, following the bright flash of light of the nuclear fireball, the explosion's [[blast wave]] would take from first light, 7 to 10 seconds to reach a person standing 3 km from the surface of the nuclear fireball, with the exact time of arrival being dependent on the [[speed of sound]] in air in their area.<ref>{{cite book|last1=Needham|first1=Charles E.|chapter=Scaling Blast Parameters|title=Blast waves|pages=157–169|date=2010|publisher=Springer Verlag|location=Heidelberg|isbn=978-3-642-05288-0|doi=10.1007/978-3-642-05288-0_12}}</ref><ref name="ReferenceB"/><ref name="ocw.nd.edu"/> The time delay between the moment of an explosion's flash and the arrival of the slower moving blast wave is analogous to the commonly experienced time delay between the observation of a flash of lightning and the arrival of [[thunder]] during a [[lightning storm]], thus at the distances that the advice would be most effective, there would be more than ample amounts of time to take the prompt countermeasure of 'duck and cover' against the blast's direct effects and flying debris.<ref name="Planning Guidance">{{cite web|url = http://www.remm.nlm.gov/PlanningGuidanceNuclearDetonation.pdf|title = Planning Guidance for Response to a Nuclear Detonation|publisher = National Library of Medicine|accessdate = 2013-11-30|edition = 2nd|publication-date = June 2010|format = PDF}}</ref> For very large explosions it can take 30 seconds or more, after the silent moment of flash, for a potentially dangerous blast wave over-pressure to arrive at, or hit, your position.<ref name="ready1">{{cite web|url=http://www.ready.gov/nuclear-blast |title=Nuclear Blast |publisher=Ready.gov |date=2013-04-17 |accessdate=2013-11-30}}</ref>
It is also worth noting that the graphs of lethal ranges of weapon effects as a function of yield, that are commonly encountered,<ref name="Mock up"/><ref name="johnstonsarchive1"/> are the unobstructed "open air", or "free air" ranges that assume amongst other things, a perfectly level target area, no passive shielding such as [[attenuate|attenuating]] effects from urban terrain masking, e.g. skyscraper shadowing, and so on. Therefore, they are thus considered to present an overestimate of the lethal ranges that would be encountered in an urban setting in the real world,<ref name="web.archive.org">{{cite web|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110706161001/http://www.usuhs.mil/afrrianniversary/events/rcsymposium/pdf/Millage.pdf|title=Wayback Machine|date=6 July 2011|publisher=}}</ref> with this being most evident following a [[ground burst]] with [[TNT equivalent|explosive yield]] similar to [[nuclear weapon design|first generation nuclear weapons]].<ref name="web.archive.org"/><ref>{{cite web |url=https://e-reports-ext.llnl.gov/pdf/348428.pdf |title=UCRL-TR-231593. Thermal Radiation from Nuclear. Detonations in Urban. Environments. R. E. Marrs, W. C. Moss, B. Whitlock. June 7, 2007}}</ref>

The building was built as a [[kimono]] shop in 1929 and was one of the "about 50" other "fair", or moderately strong, [[reinforced concrete]] buildings in central Hiroshima that remained standing following the blast and [[firestorm]] and in good structural condition, due to having a high percentage of window area which relieved blast pressure on the structural frames.<ref>{{cite book|url=http://avalon.law.yale.edu/20th_century/mp09.asp|title=The Atomic Bombings of Hiroshima and Nagasaki|chapter=Chapter 9 - General Description of Damage Caused by the Atomic Explosions|quote=In Hiroshima almost everything up to about one mile from X was completely destroyed, except for a small number (about 50) of heavily reinforced concrete buildings, most of which were specially designed to withstand earthquake shock, which were not collapsed by the blast; most of these buildings had their interiors completely gutted, and all windows, doors, sashes, and frames ripped out...While this saved the building frame, it permitted severe damage to building interior and contents, and injuries to the building occupants. Cook|date=11 July 2013|publisher=|via=Internet Archive}}</ref>]]

In contrast to these cases of survival, the unknown person sitting outside on the steps of the Sumitomo Bank next door to the Bank of Hiroshima on the morning of the bombing—and therefore fully exposed—suffered what would have eventually been lethal [[Burn#Signs and symptoms|third- to fourth-degree burns]] from the near instant [[nuclear weapon]] ''flash'' if they hadn't been killed by the slower moving blast wave when it reached them approximately one second later.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.pcf.city.hiroshima.jp/virtual/museum/index.php?l=e&no=1000 |title=Look at the Exhibits/Damage by the Heat Rays |publisher=Pcf.city.hiroshima.jp |date= |accessdate=2013-03-11}}</ref>
===Blast effects===
====Outdoors==== To elucidate the effects on lying flat on the ground in attenuating a weapons [[Explosion|blast]], Miyoko Matsubara, one of the [[Hiroshima maidens]], when recounting the bombing in an interview in 1999, said that she was outdoors and ''less than 1 mile'' from the [[hypocenter]] of the [[Little Boy]] bomb. Upon observing the nuclear weapons silent flash she quickly lay flat on the ground, while those who were standing directly next to her, and her other fellow students, had simply disappeared from her sight when the [[blast wave]] arrived and blew them away.<ref>{{cite web |url = http://www.hiroshima-spirit.jp/en/voice/miyoko_e.html|title = Continue to Relate Stupidity of War and Dignity of Life|website = The Spirit of Hiroshima|accessdate =2013-03-11|last = Matsubara|first = Miyoko}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.wagingpeace.org/articles/1999/00/00_matsubara_spirit-hiroshima.php |title=The Spirit of Hiroshima |publisher=[[Nuclear Age Peace Foundation]] |accessdate=2013-03-11 |last=Matsubara |first=Miyoko |year=1999 |quote="I quickly lay flat on the ground. Just at that moment, I heard an indescribable deafening roar. My first thought was that the plane had aimed at me"..."I had no idea how long I had lain unconscious, but when I regained consciousness the bright sunny morning had turned into night. Takiko, who had stood next to me, had simply disappeared from my sight. I could see none of my friends nor any other students. Perhaps they had been blown away by the blast." |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130420074231/http://www.wagingpeace.org/articles/1999/00/00_matsubara_spirit-hiroshima.php |archivedate=April 20, 2013 }}</ref>
Position of the body can have a considerable influence in protection from blast effects. Lying [[Prone position|prone]] on the ground will often materially lessen direct blast effects because of the protective [[defilade]] effects of irregularities in the ground surface. Ground also tends to deflect some of the blast forces upward. Standing close to a wall, even on the side from which the blast is coming, also lessens some of the effect. Orientation of the body also affects severity of the effect of blast. [[Anterior]] exposure of the body may result in lung injury, [[lateral (anatomy)|lateral]] position may result in more damage to one ear than the other, while minimal effects are to be anticipated with the [[posterior (anatomy)|posterior]] surface of the body (feet) toward the source of the blast.<ref>{{cite book |url = http://history.amedd.army.mil/booksdocs/wwii/woundblstcs/chapter2.htm|title = Wound Ballistics in World War II – Supplemented by Experiences in the Korean War|chapter = II: Ballistic Characteristics of Wounding Agents|editor-last = Coates, Jr.|editor-first = James Boyd|editor-last2 = Beyer|editor-first2 = James C.|publisher = The Historical Unit, United States Army Medical Service|lccn = 62-60002|year = 1984|location = Washington, D.C.}}</ref>
The human body is more resistant to sheer overpressure than most buildings, however, the powerful winds produced by this overpressure, as in a [[hurricane]], are capable of throwing human bodies into objects or throwing debris at high velocity, both with lethal results, rendering casualties highly dependent on surroundings.<ref name="The Nuclear Matters Handbook"/><ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.cdc.gov/niosh/docket/archive/pdfs/NIOSH-125/125-ExplosionsandRefugeChambers.pdf |title=1) Effects of blast pressure on the human body |format=PDF |date= |accessdate=2012-10-12}}</ref> For example, [[Sumiteru Taniguchi]] recounts that, while clinging to the [[earthquake|tremoring]] road surface after the [[Fat Man]] detonation, he witnessing another child being blown away, the destruction of buildings around him and stones flying through the air.<ref name="PBS">{{cite web |url= https://www.pbs.org/wgbh/peoplescentury/episodes/fallout/taniguchitranscript.html |title= Interview with Sumiteru Taniguchi Japanese Citizen, Nagasaki |accessdate=2007-08-13 |date= 1999-06-15 |website= People's Century: Fallout |publisher= PBS}}</ref> Similarly, Akihiro Takahashi and his classmates were blown by the blast of [[Little Boy]] by a distance of about 10 meters, having survived due to not colliding with any walls etc. during his flight through the air.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://history.hanover.edu/courses/excerpts/111hiroshima.html |title=Hiroshima Survivors' Testimony, Reformatted from the Original Electronic Text at Voice of Hibakusha}}</ref> Likewise, Katsuichi Hosoya had a near identical testimony.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.asahi.com/hibakusha/english/shimen/happened/happened-01.html |title='What Happened On This Date' It's hot! Help! Water please! - Hiroshima 8/6 Recreated (August 6, 2005, The Asahi Shimbun Newspaper Morning Edition) Katsuichi Hosoya has a similar account of being "blown several meters"}}</ref>
====Indoors==== In the testimony of Dr. Hiroshi Sawachika, although he was sufficiently far away from the [[Hiroshima bomb]] himself and not behind a [[Flat glass|pane of window glass]] when the blast wave arrived, those in his company who were had serious [[blast injury]] wounds, with broken glass and pieces of wood stuck into them.<ref>{{cite web |url = http://history.hanover.edu/courses/excerpts/111hiroshima.html|title = Hiroshima Survivors' Testimony – Testimony of Hiroshi Sawachika, 1986|accessdate = 15 April 2015|publisher = [[Hanover College]] History Department|last = Sawachika|first = Hiroshi}}</ref>
According to the 1946 book ''[[Hiroshima (book)|Hiroshima]]'' and other books which cover both bombings,<ref name="Robert Trumbull pg 25,28" /> in the days between the [[atomic bombings of Hiroshima and Nagasaki]], some survivors of the first bombing went to [[Nagasaki]] and told others what they had done to survive after the initial ''flash'' and informed them about the particularly dangerous threat of [[implosion (mechanical process)|imploding]] window glass. As a result of this timely warning, a number of lives were saved in the initial blast at [[Nagasaki]]. However these informed people were the exception and in both Hiroshima and Nagasaki many died while searching the skies, curious to locate the source of the brilliant flash.<ref name="Robert Trumbull pg 25,28" />
When people are indoors, running to windows to investigate the source of bright flashes in the sky still remains a common and natural response to experiencing a bright flash. Thus, although the advice to duck and cover is over half a century old, ballistic glass [[laceration]]s caused the majority of the 1000 human injuries following the [[Chelyabinsk meteor]] [[air burst]] of February 15, 2013.<ref name="Heintz"/>
The dangers of viewing explosions behind window glass was known of before the [[Atomic Age]] began, being a common source of injury and death from [[Largest artificial non-nuclear explosions|large chemical explosions]]. In the accidental [[Halifax Explosion]] of 1917, an ammunition ship exploded with the force of roughly 2.9 kilotons of [[Trinitrotoluene|TNT]],<ref name="Ruffman 1994, p.276"/> and injured the eyes and faces of hundreds of people who looked out of their windows after seeing a bright flash. Every window in the city of [[Halifax, Nova Scotia]], was shattered.<ref name="Chryssa N 1917"/>
During the 2013 [[Chelyabinsk meteor]] explosion, a fourth-grade teacher in Chelyabinsk, Yulia Karbysheva, saved 44 children from potentially life-threatening ballistic window glass cuts by ordering them to hide under their desks when she saw the flash. Despite not knowing the origin of the intense flash of light, she ordered her students to execute a duck and cover drill. Ms. Karbysheva, who herself did not duck and cover but remained standing, was seriously lacerated when the explosion's blast wave arrived, and window glass blew in, severing a tendon in one of her arms; however, not one of her students, who she ordered to hide under their desks, suffered a cut.<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2013/02/17/world/europe/russians-seek-clues-and-count-blessings-after-meteor-blast.html?_r=1& |title=After Assault From the Heavens, Russians Search for Clues and Count Blessings |newspaper=[[The New York Times]] |accessdate=2013-11-30}}</ref> A follow up study of the effects of the meteor airburst determined that the windows most prone to breaking when exposed to a [[Overpressure|blast overpressure]] are those of school buildings, which tend to be [[pressure|large in area]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://cams.seti.org/index-chelyabinsk.html|title=Cameras for Allsky Meteor Surveillance (CAMS)|publisher=}}</ref>
While the bombings of Hiroshima and Nagasaki demonstrated that the urban [[area]] of glass breakage is nearly 16 times greater than the area of significant structural/building damage, although improved building codes since then may contribute to better building survival, there would be a higher likelihood of glass breakage and therefore potential injury/death for people near windows because many modern buildings have larger windows.<ref name="nae.edu">{{cite web |url=http://www.nae.edu/Publications/Bridge/19804/19920.aspx |title= Reducing the Consequences of a Nuclear Detonation: Recent Research Author: Brooke Buddemeier, 2010 NAE}}</ref>
