G.G.Drew doi.org/10.1016/0038-092X(65)90052-6</ref> emitting in the [[ultraviolet]], [[electromagnetic spectrum|visible light]], and [[infrared]] range but with a higher [[luminous intensity|light intensity]] than sunlight, and this combination of light rays is capable of delivering [[radiance|radiant]] burning energy to exposed skin areas.<ref name="glasstonedolan">{{cite web|url=http://www.fourmilab.ch/etexts/www/effects/eonw_7.pdf |title=Thermal Radiation and Its Effects : Chapter VII |publisher=Fourmilab.ch |accessdate=2013-11-30}}</ref><ref>[https://archive.org/details/JTF3PresentsOperationGREENHOUSE1951 Joint Task Force 3 Presents Operation GREENHOUSE. ''c. 56 minutes.'' Pig skin tested behind shutters and filters]</ref><ref>Operation greenhouse. Scientific director`s report of atomic weapon tests at Eniwetok, 1951. Volume 2. Part 2. Evaluation of program</ref> While the duration of [[Thermal emittance|emittance]] of this burning thermal radiation, which can be experienced by people within range, increases with yield, it is usually at least a few seconds long.<ref>{{cite book|title=Field Manual No.1-111: Aviation Brigades|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=wbCgLzRyM6YC&pg=RA5-PA4|publisher=DIANE Publishing|isbn=978-1-4289-1102-4|page=5}}</ref>)
Great importance is given to closing [[eyelid]]s and covering the location of the eyes as temporary and permanent [[flash blindness]] is a risk potential without this covering, especially at night.<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=NjHriyuzDz4 |title=Big Picture: Individual Protection Against Atomic Attack - National Archives and Records Administration - ARC Identifier 2569661 / Local Identifier 111-TV-393 - DVD Copied by Katie Filbert - Department of Defense}}</ref>
A photograph taken about 1.3 km from the [[hypocenter]] of the [[Atomic bombings of Hiroshima and Nagasaki|Hiroshima bomb explosion]] showed that the shadowing effect of [[leaf|leaves]] from a nearby [[shrub]] protected a wooden [[utilities]] pole from [[charred|charring]] discoloration due to the burst of thermal radiation, however the rest of the telephone pole, not under the protection of the leaves, was [[pyrolysis|charred almost completely black]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.pcf.city.hiroshima.jp/virtual/VirtualMuseum_e/visit_e/subcon/he113c.html |title=Damage by the Heat Rays/Shadow Imprinted on an Electric Pole |publisher=Pcf.city.hiroshima.jp |date= |accessdate=2013-11-30}}</ref> The difference in required flash-energy necessary to produce essentially immediate, though transitory, non-propagating flaming, and that required to achieve a continued self-sustained propagating flaming are orders of magnitude in difference for most combustible materials. In the case of untreated timber it is largely dependent on the depth of char.<ref>[https://web.archive.org/web/20180728212952/http://www.dtic.mil/dtic/tr/fulltext/u2/009336.pdf project 5046 pg 12]</ref><ref>Evaluation of Thermal Effects on Specimens Exposed at Bikini (NML Project 5046, Part 7, Confidential) (March, 1950).</ref><ref>Investigation of Radiation Effects on Wood Specimens Exposed During the Able Test at Bikini</ref>
===Initial nuclear radiation=== {{See also|Neutron emission#Neutron emission in fission|Armed Forces Radiobiology Research Institute|Dosimetry|Orders of magnitude (radiation)|Dose fractionation|Radiation-induced cancer|Treatment of infections after exposure to ionizing radiation}} While not designed for those faced with low-yield [[neutron bomb]]s or for those who are, in general, so close to the nuclear fireball that prompt/initial radiation would be [[LD50|life-threatening in the short-medium term]], ducking and covering would nevertheless slightly reduce exposure to the ''initial'' [[gamma ray]]s, specifically the portion emitted after the first flash of visible light.<ref name="nationalarchives1">{{cite web|url=http://discovery.nationalarchives.gov.uk/SearchUI/Details/AssetMain?iaid=C1271982 |title=The advantage of lying prone in reducing the dose of gamma rays from an airburst atomic... | The National Archives |publisher=Discovery.nationalarchives.gov.uk |date= |accessdate=2013-11-30}}</ref> The initial gamma rays are defined as those emitted from the fireball & following mushroom cloud which can reach personnel on the ground for a total of approximately 1 minute, at which point the intensity of the radiation has diminished and the atmosphere itself is thick enough to act as full shielding.<ref name="acq.osd.mil">{{cite web|url=http://www.acq.osd.mil/ncbdp/nm/nm_book_5_11/appendix_F.htm |title=The Nuclear Matters Handbook |quote="For surface and low-air bursts, the fireball will rise quickly, and within approximately one minute, it will be at an altitude high enough similar that none of the gamma radiation produced inside the fireball will have any impact to people or equipment on the ground. For this reason, initial nuclear radiation is defined as the nuclear radiation produced within one minute post-detonation. Initial nuclear radiation is also called prompt nuclear radiation." |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130302091606/http://www.acq.osd.mil/ncbdp/nm/nm_book_5_11/appendix_F.htm |archivedate=2013-03-02 |df= }}</ref><ref>{{cite book|chapterurl = http://ke.army.mil/bordeninstitute/published_volumes/nuclearwarfare/chapter1/chapter1.pdf |deadurl = no| archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20161229163720/https://ke.army.mil/bordeninstitute/published_volumes/nuclearwarfare/chapter1/chapter1.pdf|archivedate = 23 December 2016|publisher = Borden Institute|chapter = Chapter 1 - Nuclear Events and Their Consequences|title = Medical Consequences of Nuclear Warfare|last1= Alt|first1 = Leonard A.|last2= Forcino|first2= C. Douglas |last3 = Walker|first3 = Richard I.}}</ref><ref name="fas.org">{{cite web |url=https://fas.org/nuke/guide/usa/doctrine/dod/fm8-9/1ch3.htm |title=CHAPTER 3 EFFECTS OF NUCLEAR EXPLOSIONS SECTION I – GENERAL}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20180515201022/http://www.oektg.at/wp-content/uploads/02-Nuclear-Engineering-Overview1.pdf|title=Wayback Machine|date=15 May 2018|publisher=}}</ref>
As approximately half of these gamma rays are emitted in the first second and the other half, over the following 59<ref>[''Desert Rock VI Exercise: "The Atom Soldier" 1955 US Army; The Big Picture TV-308'' circa 15 mins 30 secs]</ref> alongside gamma rays being mostly emitted in a straight line, people laying on the ground will more likely have obstacles serving as [[radiation protection]] such as building walls, foundations, car engines, etc. between their bodies and the radiation emitted from both the fireball and the accompanying lower levels of radiation that continue to arrive at the ground for about 1 minute, during the mushroom cloud phase, which is termed "[[cloudshine]]".<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.remm.nlm.gov/nuclearexplosion.htm|title=Nuclear Detonation: Weapons, Improvised Nuclear Devices - Radiation Emergency Medical Management|publisher=}}</ref> It would also give protection from the even smaller fraction of radiation that changes direction and is randomly [[Compton scattering|reflected and scattered]] by the air/"[[skyshine]]".<ref name="books.google.com">{{cite web|url=https://books.google.com/?id=opAklHndAy8C&pg=PA6&dq=%22fukuryu+maru%22+ash|title=Structure shielding against fallout gamma rays from nuclear detonations|first1=Lewis Van Clief|last1=Spencer|first2=Arthur B.|last2=Chilton|first3=Charles|last3=Eisenhauer|first4=Center for Radiation|last4=Research|first5=United States National Bureau of|last5=Standards|first6=University of Illinois at|last6=Urbana-Champaign|date=1 January 1980|publisher=U.S. Dept. of Commerce, National Bureau of Standards|via=Google Books}}</ref> Approximately "One and one half inches"/37 mm of [[steel]] will reduce gamma dose by half.<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=NjHriyuzDz4 |title=Big Picture: Individual Protection Against Atomic Attack - National Archives and Records Administration - ARC Identifier 2569661 / Local Identifier 111-TV-393 - DVD Copied by Katie Filbert - Department of Defense. Circa 10:20 minutes in}}</ref> Its [[Radiation protection#Shielding|half-value thickness]].
The effective gamma ray energy of the cloudshine is not especially high, 200 [[KeV]].<ref>{{Cite journal|title=Operation Greenhouse. Scientific Director's report of atomic weapon tests at Eniwetok, 1951. Annex 6. 8. cloud radiation field|date=1 April 1985|publisher=US government|osti = 7248965}}</ref>
Unlike the relatively [[TNT equivalent|low-yield]], or low explosive energy "[[A-bomb]]s" dropped on Hiroshima and Nagasaki, which did result in a sizable proportion of injuries from prompt radiation, higher yield "[[hydrogen bomb]]s" ([[thermonuclear]] weapons) are not expected to result in very many such injuries – as the range at which the [[ionizing radiation]] from higher yield devices is of primary concern, is already well inside the hyper-lethal blast and flash burn areas.<ref name="Mock up"/><ref name = negligible/>
===Delayed nuclear radiation, "fallout"=== {{See also|Neptunium-239|Iodine-131|Black Rain (novel)|Potassium iodide|Human decontamination|Water curtain/Countermeasure washdown system|Project 4.1|Nuclear War Survival Skills|Textbook of Military Medicine}} Apart from the intrinsic "prompt effects" of nuclear detonations, that of thermal flash, blast and initial radiation releases, if any part of the fireball of the nuclear detonation contacts the ground, in what is known as a [[surface burst]], another, comparatively slowly increasing, radiation hazard will also begin to form in the immediate area.<ref name="nuchandb">{{cite book|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=CAUYAAAAYAAJ&pg=PA18&dq=%22beta+burns%22&cd=65#v=onepage&q=%22beta%20burns%22&f=false |title=Nuclear handbook for medical service personnel|author=United States. Dept. of the Army|page=18|year=1990}}</ref><ref name="medmagrad">{{cite book|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=Y-k5h07NkFcC&pg=PA77&dq=%22beta+burns%22&cd=7#v=onepage&q=%22beta%20burns%22&f=false |title=Medical management of radiation accidents|author1=Igor A. Gusev |author2=Angelina Konstantinovna Guskova |author3=Fred Albert Mettler |page=77|publisher=CRC Press|year=2001|isbn=978-0-8493-7004-5}}</ref>
Putting aside the possibility of the detonation occurring during an already established heavy rain-storm, the formation of this life-threatening "[[nuclear fallout|delayed nuclear radiation]]" manifests only when the altitude, or "[[airburst|height of burst]]" of the explosion, is such that both the fireball and the [[buoyant]] updrafts it creates, sufficiently heats and lifts the [[soil]] that was below it into the core of the mushroom cloud. Once there, the very hot [[radioactive isotope]] products of the [[nuclear reaction]]s that produced the explosion, begin to [[:wikt:coalesce|coalesce]] with the cooler and denser soil. Upon cooling, this mixture begins to locally ''[[nuclear fallout|fall-out]]'' or [[precipitate]]-out of the [[mushroom cloud]], falling back to the surface of the earth, near to the point of detonation, over the next few minutes and hours.<ref name="theatlantic.com">{{cite web|url=https://www.theatlantic.com/national/archive/2011/01/the-unexpected-return-of-duck-and-cover/68776/|title=The Unexpected Return of 'Duck and Cover'|first=Glenn Harlan|last=Reynolds|website=The Atlantic|date = 4 January 2011}}</ref>
While the duck and cover countermeasure, in its most basic form, offers a small to negligible protection against [[fallout]], the technique assumes that after the effects of the blast and initial radiation subside, with the latter of which being no longer a threat after about "twenty seconds" to 1 minute post detonation,<ref name="acq.osd.mil"/><ref name="books.google.com"/> a person who ducks and covers will realize when it is wise to cease ducking and covering (after the blast and initial radiation danger has passed) and to then seek out a more sheltered area, like an established or improvised [[fallout shelter]] to protect themselves from the ensuing potential [[nuclear fallout|local fallout]] danger, as depicted in the [[Duck and Cover (film)|film]].
After all, "Duck and Cover" is a first response countermeasure only, in much the same way that "Drop, Cover and Hold On" is during an earthquake, with the advice having served its purpose once the earthquake has passed, and possibly other dangers—like a [[tsunami]] or fallout—may be looming, which then require movement to high ground and radiation protection, respectively.
However, if such a shelter is unavailable, the person should then be advised to follow the [[Shelter in Place]] protocol, or if given, [[emergency evacuation]] advice. Evacuation orders would entail exiting the area completely by following a path [[perpendicular]] to the [[wind direction]], and therefore perpendicular to the path of the fallout [[plume (hydrodynamics)|plume]].<ref name="autogenerated1">{{cite web|url=https://www.dhs.gov/xlibrary/assets/prep_nuclear_fact_sheet.pdf |title=Nuclear Attack |publisher=U.S. Department of Homeland Security |accessdate=|date = 2005}}</ref> Taking upper atmospheric winds into account, surface winds alone are not to be depended upon as indicative of the direction of fallout movement.<ref>[https://archive.org/details/Radiolog1961 radiological defense 1961 ''c 12 minutes'']</ref> "Sheltering in place" is staying indoors, in a preferably [[airtight|sealed tight]] basement, or internal room, for a number of hours, with the oxygen supply available in such a scenario being more than sufficient for 3+ hours in even the smallest average room, under the assumption that the improvised seal is perfect, until [[carbon dioxide]] levels begin to reach [[Hypercapnia|unsafe values]] and necessitate room unsealing for a number of minutes to create a room [[Air changes per hour|air change]].<ref>{{cite web |url=http://orise.orau.gov/csepp/documents/planning/reports/misc-reports/paperSIP010406.pdf |title=Journal of Hazardous Materials A119 (2005) 31–40 Effectiveness of expedient sheltering in place in a residence, James J. Jetter, Calvin Whitfield |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20131111103357/http://orise.orau.gov/csepp/documents/planning/reports/misc-reports/paperSIP010406.pdf |archivedate=2013-11-11 |df= }}</ref><ref>{{cite journal |title=A systems approach to the design of safe-rooms for shelter-in-place | doi=10.1007/S12273-009-9301-2 | volume=2 |journal=Building Simulation |pages=41–51|year = 2009|last1 = Bennett|first1 = James S}} {{subscription required}}</ref>
In the era the advice was originally given, the most common nuclear weapons were weapons comparable to the US [[Fat Man]] and Soviet [[Joe-1]] in yield. The most far-reaching dangers that initially come from the nuclear explosion of this, and higher, yield weapons as [[airburst]]s, are the initial flash/heat and blast effects and not from [[fallout]]. This is due to the fact that when nuclear weapons are detonated to maximize the range of building destruction, that is, maximize the range of surface blast damage, an [[airburst]] is the preferred [[proximity fuze|nuclear fuzing]] height,<ref>{{cite book|title = Critical Assembly: A Technical History of Los Alamos During the Oppenheimer Years, 1943-1945|last1 =Hoddeson|first1 = Lillian|last2 = Henriksen|first2 = Paul W. |last3 = Meade|first3 = Roger A.|last4 = Westfall|first4= Catherine|date = 1993|pages=183–184|url = https://books.google.com/?id=kBBu7lTJc4EC&printsec=frontcover#v=onepage&q&f=false|isbn = 9780521441322|publisher = Cambridge University Press}}</ref>{{sfn|Hawkins|1961|pp=98–99}} as it exploits the [[Blast wave#Mach Stem Formation|mach stem]] phenomenon. This phenomenon of a blast wave occurs when the blast reaches the ground and is reflected. Below a certain reflection angle the reflected wave and the incident wave merge and form a reinforced horizontal wave; this is known as the 'Mach stem' (named after [[Ernst Mach]]) and is a form of [[constructive interference]] and consequently extends the range of high pressure.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.atomicarchive.com/Effects/effects6.shtml |title=The Mach Stem | Effects of Nuclear Weapons |publisher=atomicarchive.com |date= |accessdate=2014-04-26}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.fas.org/nuke/intro/nuke/blast.htm |title=Nuclear Weapon Blast Effects |publisher=Fas.org |date= |accessdate=2014-04-26}}</ref><ref>[http://www.atomicarchive.com/Movies/machstem.shtml] video of the mach 'Y' stem, note that it is not a phenomenon unique to nuclear explosions, conventional explosions also produce it.</ref><ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.dtic.mil/dtic/tr/fulltext/u2/a159214.pdf |title=MACH STEM MODELING WITH SPHERICAL SHOCK WAVES, AFIT/GNE/ENP/85M-6 by William E. Eichinger, 1985}}</ref> Air-burst fuzing also increases the range that people's skin will have a [[line-of-sight propagation|line-of-sight]] with the nuclear fireball. However, as a result of the high altitude of the explosion, most of the radioactive bomb debris is dispersed into the [[stratosphere]], with a great [[Radiation shielding#Shielding design|column of air]] therefore placed between the vast majority of the bomb debris/[[fission products|fission reaction products]] and people on the ground for a number of crucial days before it [[fallout|falls out]] of the atmosphere in a comparatively dilute fashion. This "delayed fallout" is henceforth not an immediate concern to those near the blast. On the other hand, the only time that fallout is rapidly concentrated in a potentially lethal fashion in the local/regional area around the explosion is when the nuclear fireball makes contact with the ground surface, with an explosion that does so, being aptly termed a [[surface burst]].<ref name="fourmilab.ch">{{cite web|url=http://www.fourmilab.ch/etexts/www/effects/ |title=The Effects of Nuclear Weapons |publisher=Fourmilab.ch |date= |accessdate=2013-11-30}}</ref> For example, in the [[Operation Crossroads]] tests of 1946 on [[Bikini Atoll]], using two explosive devices of the same design and yield, the first, Test Able (an air burst) had little local fallout, but the infamous Test Baker (a near surface shallow underwater burst) left the local test targets badly contaminated with radioactive fallout.
Widespread radioactive fallout itself was not recognized as a threat among the public at large before 1954, until the widely publicized story of the 15-megaton surface burst of the experimental test shot [[Castle Bravo]] on the [[Marshall Islands]]. The explosive yield of the [[Castle Bravo]] device ''the Shrimp'' was unexpectedly high, and therefore correspondingly higher amounts of local fallout were produced. When this arrived at their location carried by the wind, this caused the 23 crew members on a Japanese fishing boat known as the [[Daigo Fukuryū Maru|Lucky Dragon]] to come down with [[acute radiation sickness]] with varying degrees of seriousness<ref name="massburns">{{cite book|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=sDQrAAAAYAAJ&pg=PA248&dq=%22beta+burns%22&cd=5#v=onepage&q=%22beta%20burns%22&f=false |page=248|title=Mass burns: proceedings of a workshop, 13–14 March 1968|author=National Research Council (U.S.). Committee on Fire Research, United States. Office of Civil Defense|publisher=National Academies|year=1969}}</ref> and due to complications in the treatment of the ship's radio operator months after the exposure, resulted in his death.
It is, however, unlikely that a well-funded [[belligerent]] with nuclear weapons would waste their weapons with fuzing to explode below or on the surface, as both test [[Operation Crossroads|shot Baker]], and [[Castle Bravo]] were respectively. Instead, to maximize the range of city blast destruction and immediate death, an air burst is preferred,<ref name="fourmilab.ch"/> as the ≈500 meter explosion heights of the only nuclear weapons used on cities, [[Little Boy]] and [[Fat Man]] also attest to.<ref>[[Kenneth Nichols|Nichols, K. D.]] "The Road to Trinity" pages 175, 198, 223 (1987, Morrow, New York) {{ISBN|0-688-06910-X}}</ref> Moreover, with air bursts the total amount of radiation contained in the fallout, in units of activity/[[becquerel]], is somewhat less than the total that would be released from a surface or subsurface burst, as in comparison, depending on the height of burst, little to no [[neutron activation]] or neutron induced gamma activity of soil occurs from air bursts.<ref>{{cite book|title = Disaster Medicine |edition = 2nd |year = 2007 |editor-first = David E. |editor-last = Hogan|url = https://books.google.com/books?id=hgLccSb8DIUC&printsec=frontcover#v=onepage&q&f=false|page = 384 |chapter = Nuclear Detonations: Evaluation and Response|last = Fong|first = Fun H., Jr.|isbn = 9780781762625 }}</ref> Therefore, the initial danger from concentrated local/'early' [[fallout]] (which takes on the color of the soil around the fireball, commonly with a dusty [[pumice]] or [[wood ash|ash]]-like appearance, as experienced by the crew of the [[Daigo Fukuryū Maru|Lucky Dragon]]) remains low in a global nuclear war scenario. Instead the fallout most likely to be encountered by most survivors in this scenario is expected to be the less dangerous but widely spread global/'late' [[fallout]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.fourmilab.ch/etexts/www/effects/ |title=The Effects of Nuclear Weapons, chapter IX |publisher=Fourmilab.ch |date= |accessdate=2013-03-11}}</ref> An air burst at optimum height will produce a negligible amount of early fallout.<ref>Fong (2007), pp. 384 & 385</ref>
A notable comparison to underline this is found when one compares the 50 megaton air-burst [[Tsar Bomba]], which produced no concentrated local/early fallout, and thus no known deaths from radiation, with the surface burst of the 15 megaton [[Castle Bravo]], which in comparison, due to the local fallout produced, was implicated in the death of 1 of 23 crew on the [[Daigo Fukuryū Maru|Lucky Dragon]] and made the entire [[Bikini Atoll]] unfit for further nuclear testing until enough time elapsed and the intensity of the radiation field had [[radioactive decay|decayed]] to acceptable levels.<ref group=note>By 1958, a total of 23 nuclear devices were exploded on or near the atoll,{{cite web|url=http://www.bikiniatoll.com/BIKINICORALS.pdf |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2013-08-13 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20131029195238/http://www.bikiniatoll.com/BIKINICORALS.pdf |archivedate=2013-10-29 |df= }} with the majority occurring after the 1954 [[Operation Castle]] series, resulting in a total of about 42 megatons of pure [[fission product]] fallout being generated around the atoll. This made permanent above ground habitation without [[Environmental remediation|remediation]] unwise for a decade or so; it was thus resettled in 1968. The inhabitants lived there again from 1968 to 1978, abandoning the atoll in 1978. As of 2014, the atoll has had infrequent inhabitants since the 1990s, mainly for tours – a return to permanent safe habitation would require locally produced and consumed plant food to be grown with fertilizer, or alternatively, only imported plant food to be eaten.[http://www-ns.iaea.org/appraisals/bikini-atoll.asp] [http://www.outsideonline.com/outdoor-adventure/nature/Paradise-With-An-Asterisk.html]</ref>
[[File:OperationDoorstep1-BasementMother.jpg|thumb|left|An [[Operation Doorstep]] mother and daughter [[mannequin]] pair in an improvised basement [[lean-to]] shelter prior to testing in [[Upshot-Knothole Annie]]. To shelter-in-place in such an area would offer, in a number of outdoor dose rates, an adequate fallout radiation protection factor (PF) or "dose reduction factor" of 20 or more.<ref name="Planning Guidance"/> More effective basement spaces did/do exist however, of "10 million" homes assessed in 1968, 500,000 US basements were found to have a PF-40.<ref name="books.google.com"/><ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.training.fema.gov/EMIWeb/edu/docs/HistoricalInterest/Office%20of%20Civil%20Defense%20-%201968%20-%20Annual%20Report.pdf |title=Annual report of the office of civil defense 1968. National Fallout Shelter Survey pg 29,37-38}}</ref>]] Furthermore, regardless of if a nuclear attack on a city is of the surface or air-burst variety or a mixture of both, the advice to [[shelter in place]], in the interior of well-built homes, or if available, [[fallout shelter]]s, as suggested in the film ''[[Duck and Cover (film)|Duck and Cover]]'', will drastically reduce one's chance of absorbing a hazardous dose of radiation.<ref>{{cite web |url=https://travel.state.gov/travel/tips/health/health_1184.html |title=Radiological and Nuclear Incidents |publisher=Travel.state.gov |date= |accessdate=2013-03-11 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130316000711/http://travel.state.gov/travel/tips/health/health_1184.html |archivedate=2013-03-16 |df= }}</ref> A real-world example of this occurred after the [[Castle Bravo]] test where, in contrast to the crew of the [[Daigo Fukuryū Maru|Lucky Dragon]], the firing crew that triggered the explosion safely sheltered in their firing station until after a number of hours had passed and the radiation levels outside fell to dose rate levels safe enough for an evacuation to be considered.<ref name="Dr. John C. Clark as told to Robert Cahn">{{cite web|url=http://www.sonicbomb.com/content/atomic/docs/trapped_by_radioactive_fallout.pdf|author= Dr. John C. Clark as told to Robert Cahn|title= Trapped by Radioactive Fallout, ''Saturday Evening Post''|date= July 1957}} accessed Feb 20, 2013</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.dgely.com/Bikini/Nuclear%20Testing/Operation%20Castle/Operation%20Castle%20Bravo%20Blast.htm |title=Operation Castle Bravo Blast |publisher=Dgely.com |date= |accessdate=2013-11-30}}</ref> The comparative safety experienced by the Castle Bravo firing crew served as a [[proof of concept]] to [[civil defense]] personnel that [[shelter in place]] (or "buttoning up" as it was known then) is an effective strategy in mitigating the potentially serious health effects of local fallout.<ref name="Dr. John C. Clark as told to Robert Cahn"/>
The minimum typical protection factor of the [[fallout shelter]]s in US cities is 40 or more. In many cases these shelters are nothing more than the interior of pre-existing well-built buildings that have been inspected, and following their protection factors being calculated, re-purposed as fallout shelters.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://archive.org/details/radioactive_fallout_and_shelter |title=Radioactive Fallout and Shelter : U S Office Of Civil Defense : Free Download & Streaming : Internet Archive |publisher=Archive.org |date= |accessdate=2013-11-30}}</ref><ref name="books.google.com"/><ref>{{cite web |url=http://home.howstuffworks.com/home-improvement/household-safety/tips/fallout-shelter2.htm |title=How Fallout Shelters Work|publisher = HowStuffWorks.com|last = Fuller|first = John|date = 7 April 2008}}</ref><ref name="Journals.cambridge.org">{{cite web|url=http://journals.cambridge.org/action/displayAbstract?fromPage=online&aid=7805718 |title=Architects of Armageddon: the Home Office Scientific Advisers' Branch and civil defence in Britain, 1945–68 |publisher=Journals.cambridge.org |date= |accessdate=2013-03-11}}</ref>
A protection factor of at least 40 means that the [[radiation shielding]] provided by the shelter reduces the radiation dose experienced by at least 40 times that which would be experienced outside the shelter with no shielding. "Protection factor" is equivalent to the modern term "dose reduction factor".<ref name="Planning Guidance"/>
[[Image:Fallout G&D77.JPG|thumb|In units of [[Rad (unit)|rads]], this is a simplistic model ([[Gauss]]ian) of a wind-blown fallout map,<ref name="nae.edu"/> which depicts the unshielded ground level fallout [[gamma ray]] dose and [[dose rate]] contours expected to follow a 2 megaton land surface burst detonation, with 1 megaton of the yield coming from [[Nuclear fission|fission]] reactions. Because of radioactive decay, the dose rate [[contour line|contours]] (on the right) contract after fallout has arrived, but the total [[absorbed dose]] contours (left) continue to grow. A similar color version of the right panel, dose rate contour plot, for a 0.1 to 10 kiloton surface burst is also available.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.remm.nlm.gov/PlanningGuidanceNuclearDetonation.pdf |title=Planning Guidance for Response to a Nuclear Detonation (figure 1.8) |publisher=Remm.nlm.gov |accessdate=2013-11-30}}</ref> [[acute toxicity|Acutely dangerous]] regions of fallout are accompanied by fallout particles which are large enough to be detected by eye during its falling out/[[deposition (aerosol physics)|deposition]], that is, they are equal to or larger than the size of [[dust]].<ref name="nae.edu"/><ref name="books.google.com"/> All of the [[Acute radiation syndrome|ARS]] deaths following the [[Chernobyl accident]] were due to external [[beta burns]]. The [[beta particle]] to gamma energy ratio is [[Radiation burn#Radioactive fallout|usually greater than 3 in the timeframe of fallout]] with the greatest threat to life. Protection from physical contact with the dust therefore greatly reduces radiation exposure.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.nationalacademies.org/hmd/~/media/Files/Activity%20Files/PublicHealth/NucEventPrepWS/METTLERIOMNuclearWorkshop1.pdf|title=Nuclear fallout medical effects. Mettler|publisher=}}</ref> The beta decaying [[uranium-237]] and [[neptunium-239]], that are generated from the [[neutron capture]] of U-235 and Pu-239 respectively, are regarded as the leading hazardous radioisotopes in the first hour-to-week period following [[nuclear fallout]], with Np-239 dominating "the spectrum for several days".<ref>[Film Badge Dosimetry in Atmospheric Nuclear Tests, By Committee on Film Badge Dosimetry in Atmospheric Nuclear Tests, Commission on Engineering and Technical Systems, Division on Engineering and Physical Sciences, National Research Council. pp. 24-35]</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.dtra.mil/Portals/61/Documents/NTPR/4-Rad_Exp_Rpts/30_DTRA-TR-07-5_Fractionation_Report.pdf|title=Bounding Analysis of Effects of Fractionation of Radionuclides in Fallout on Estimation of Doses to Atomic Veterans DTRA-TR-07-5. 2007|publisher=}}</ref>]]
During the first hour after a nuclear explosion, radioactivity levels drop precipitously. Radioactivity levels are further reduced by about 90% after another 7 hours and by about 99% after 2 days.<ref name="autogenerated1"/> An accurate rule of thumb, applicable in the time-period of days to a few weeks post-detonation which approximates the radioactive dose rate generated by the decay of the myriad of isotopes present in nuclear fallout, is the "[[Nuclear fallout#The Seven Ten Rule|7/10 rule]]".<ref name="radiological defense 1961">[https://archive.org/details/Radiolog1961 radiological defense 1961]</ref><ref name="theatlantic.com"/> The rule states that for each 7-fold increase in time the dose rate drops by a factor of 10.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www3.nd.edu/~nsl/Lectures/phys205/pdf/Nuclear_Warfare_9.pdf |title=Radiation Effects of a Nuclear Bomb |publisher=3.nd.edu |accessdate=2013-11-30}}</ref> For example, assuming the fallout process has ended 24 hours post detonation and the dose rate would be lethal if a few hours of exposure occurred, 50 [[Roentgen (unit)|roentgens]] per hour, then 7 days after detonation the dose rate will be 5 R/hr and 49 days after detonation (7×7 days) the dose rate will be 0.5 R/hr at which point no special precautions would need to be taken and venturing outside into that dose rate for an hour or two would pose a close to negligible health hazard,<ref name="radiological defense 1961"/><ref>{{cite web|url=http://nikealaska.org/nuke/fallout.html |title=Understanding Radioactive Fallout |publisher=Nikealaska.org |date=2006-01-07 |accessdate=2013-11-30}}</ref> thus permitting an evacuation to be done with acceptable safety to a known contamination free zone. Following a surface-burst nuclear detonation, approximately 80 percent of the fallout would be deposited on the ground during the first 24 hours.<ref name="ready1"/>
Some agencies that promoted "evacuate immediately" guidance as a response to potentially lethal fallout arriving, advice which may have been influenced by these agencies assuming simplistic single wind-driven [[cigar]]/[[Gauss]]ian shaped fallout contours would be representative of reality, have since retracted this advice. This can actually result in higher radiation exposures as it would put people outdoors and in harm's way when the radiation levels would be highest. The Modeling and Analysis Coordination Working Group (MACWG) – which was set up to resolve conflicting advice given by various agencies, has reaffirmed that the best blanket advice that would reduce the number of casualties by the greatest amount is: "Early, adequate sheltering followed by informed, delayed evacuation."<ref name="nae.edu"/>
Expert advice published in the 2010 document ''Planning Guidance for Response to a Nuclear Detonation'' is to [[shelter in place]], in an area away from building fires, for at least 1 to 2 hours following a nuclear detonation and fallout arriving,<ref name="Planning Guidance"/> and the greatest benefit, assuming personnel are in a building with a high protection factor, is sheltering for no less than 12 to 24 hours before evacuation.<ref name="Planning Guidance"/> Therefore, sheltering for the first few hours can save lives.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.remm.nlm.gov/nuclearexplosion.htm |title=Nuclear Detonation: Weapons, Improvised Nuclear Devices - Radiation Emergency Medical Management |publisher=Remm.nlm.gov |date= |accessdate=2013-11-30}}</ref> Indeed, death and injury from local fallout is regarded by experts as the most preventable of all the effects of a nuclear detonation, being simply dependent on if personnel know how to identify an adequate shelter when they see one and enter one quickly, with the number of potential people saved being cited as in the hundreds of thousands.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=ChZUuM-uJ0E |title=Reducing consequences of nuclear detonation |publisher=YouTube |date= |accessdate=2013-11-30}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=ttv1NLf6Cs4 |title=Brooke Buddemeier, Nuclear Detonation in a Major City |publisher=YouTube |date=2011-06-21 |accessdate=2013-11-30}}</ref><ref name="prod.sandia.gov">{{cite web |url=http://prod.sandia.gov/techlib/access-control.cgi/2011/119092.pdf |title=Analysis of Sheltering and Evacuation Strategies for a National Capital Region Nuclear Detonation Scenario, SANDIA REPORT, SAND 2011-9092 Unlimited Release Published December 2011. Authors: Larry D. Brandt, Ann S. Yoshimura}}</ref><ref name="Urban Nuclear Detonation Scenario 2009">{{cite web |url=http://prod.sandia.gov/techlib/access-control.cgi/2009/093299.pdf |title=Analysis of Sheltering and Evacuation Strategies for an Urban Nuclear Detonation Scenario (Los Angeles) SANDIA REPORT SAND2009-3299 Unlimited Release Printed May 2009, Authors: Larry D. Brandt, Ann S. Yoshimura}}</ref> Or even higher if the remaining occupants of the city are made aware of the contaminated areas, by emergency systems, within hours of the event's aftermath.<ref name="prod.sandia.gov"/><ref>{{Cite book |title=Social Computing, Behavioral-Cultural Modeling and Prediction Lecture Notes in Computer Science Volume 7812, 2013, pp 476-485 Modeling the Interaction between Emergency Communications and Behavior in the Aftermath of a Disaster|volume = 7812|pages = 476–485|doi = 10.1007/978-3-642-37210-0_52|chapter = Modeling the Interaction between Emergency Communications and Behavior in the Aftermath of a Disaster|series = Lecture Notes in Computer Science|year = 2013|last1 = Chandan|first1 = Shridhar|last2 = Saha|first2 = Sudip|last3 = Barrett|first3 = Chris|last4 = Eubank|first4 = Stephen|last5 = Marathe|first5 = Achla|last6 = Marathe|first6 = Madhav|last7 = Swarup|first7 = Samarth|last8 = Vullikanti|first8 = Anil Kumar S|isbn = 978-3-642-37209-4}}</ref> In 2009 to 2013 a further iteration on sheltering-in-place was made to determine the optimal improvised fallout-shelter-residence-times following a nuclear detonation, with computer analysis, and including a summary of prior studies and guidance. It was found that individuals should quickly get into the best intact building at least under 5 minutes distant in travel time following the detonation, and they should stay there for at least 30 minutes before venturing out to find a shelter with a higher protection factor but that is a greater travel time away than 10 minutes.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://newatlas.com/survive-nuclear-bomb-shelter/31057/|title=How to survive a nuclear bomb: An update on "Duck and Cover"|publisher=|website = New Atlas|last = Dodson|first = Brian|date = 12 March 2014}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.thejournal.ie/what-to-do-when-theres-an-atomic-bomb-1265502-Jan2014/|title=Where to hide if a nuclear bomb is dropped on your city…|first=Business|last=Insider|publisher=}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.sciencenews.org/blog/gory-details/nuclear-attack-there%E2%80%99s-no-avoiding-brutal-math|title=In a nuclear attack, there's no avoiding the brutal math|first=Erika|last=Engelhaupt|date=29 January 2014|publisher=}}</ref><ref>{{cite journal|url=http://rspa.royalsocietypublishing.org/content/470/2163/20130693|title=Determining optimal fallout shelter times following a nuclear detonation|first=Michael B.|last=Dillon|date=8 March 2014|journal=Proc. R. Soc. A|volume=470|issue=2163|pages=20130693|via=rspa.royalsocietypublishing.org|doi=10.1098/rspa.2013.0693}}</ref> However, although this would be effective in cases where the initial building protection factor is less than about 10, it requires a high degree of individual [[situational awareness]] that may be optimistic to assume following the shock of a nuclear detonation. If a building with a PF of 20 or more is nearby, such as the fallout shelters depicted in the [[Duck and Cover (film)|film]], in the vast majority of fallout circumstances, it would not be advisable to leave it until 3+ hours have elapsed following the initial arrival of the local fallout.<ref name="prod.sandia.gov"/><ref name="Urban Nuclear Detonation Scenario 2009"/>
Following a single IND (improvised nuclear device) detonation in the US, the [[National Atmospheric Release Advisory Center]] (NARAC) would, within minutes to at most hours, after the detonation have a reliable prediction of the fallout plume size and direction. When armed with this prediction they would then begin attempting to corroborate this with readings from radiation [[survey meter]] equipment that would [[nap of the earth|fly over close to the ground]] in the affected area by means of helicopter or drone ([[UAV]]) aircraft on [[Materials MASINT|material intelligence]] gathering missions,<ref>[https://archive.org/details/Radiolog1961 radiological defense 1961. ''c 18 minutes'']</ref> which would also follow within tens of minutes to at most hours after the detonation.<ref group=note>As this ground hugging [[Aerial survey|fly over]] has the potential to be mistaken for [[airlift]] rescue attempts, which are common after other [[natural disasters]], survivors should not exit shelter unless absolutely necessary in the time period before being informed of the fallout situation, or alternatively, stay in shelter until sufficient time has elapsed, +24 hrs for a delayed evacuation to take place.</ref>
Once a general outline and direction of the fallout is determined, disseminating this information to citizens sheltering-in-place would soon follow, by means of [[loudspeaker]], radio, cell phone etc., with a "Fallout App" containing maps for [[smart phone]]s being regarded as an area of interest so that survivors don't inadvertently evacuate downwind further into harm's way.<ref name="ReferenceA">{{cite web |url=http://www.nae.edu/Publications/Bridge/19804/19892.aspx |title= A Nuclear Explosion in a City or an Attack on a Nuclear Reactor Author: Richard L. Garwin, 2010}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.remm.nlm.gov/nuclearexplosion.htm |title=Nuclear Detonation: Weapons, Improvised Nuclear Devices, Communicating After an IND Detonation: Resource for Responders and Officials}}</ref> A number of questions the affected public are likely to have after a nuclear detonation have been compiled and pre-answered to help communications in the immediate aftermath.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.fema.gov/media-library-data/20130726-1919-25045-0618/communicating_in_the_immediate_aftermath__final_june_2013_508_ok.pdf|title=Improvised Nuclear Devices, Communicating in the immediate aftermath. FEMA 2013|publisher=}}</ref><ref>{{Cite book|url=http://www.nap.edu/catalog/18347/nationwide-response-issues-after-an-improvised-nuclear-device-attack-medical|title=Nationwide Response Issues After an Improvised Nuclear Device Attack: Medical and Public Health Considerations for Neighboring Jurisdictions: Workshop Summary|first=Institute of|last=Medicine|date=9 July 2013|publisher=|doi=10.17226/18347|pmid=24199263|isbn=978-0-309-28601-5}}</ref>
===Nuclear electromagnetic pulse, non-lethal=== {{See also|National Response Scenario Number One}} In respect to the other non-lethal weapon effects from an IND detonated on or near the surface, the detonation's blast wave would likely produce a momentary electric grid [[Power outage|blackout]] due to the loss of a large portion of a city's electrical equipment drawing power/[[electrical load]], while the [[electromagnetic pulse]] (EMP) from a surface/ground-burst explosion would cause little damage outside the blast area, so [[cell phone]] towers that survive the blast should be capable of carrying communications.<ref name="ReferenceA"/> But if [[Communication during the September 11 attacks#General public|communications during the 9/11 attacks]] or after a major hurricane are anything to go by, and the cell phone [[cell tower|network towers]] survive, the service would be overloaded (a [[mass call event]]) and thereby made useless soon after; however, if prior arrangements between the cell network and [[emergency responders]] are made to give them priority and bar access to all other individuals, then it may be an effective service.
The Civil Defense (CD) shelters, as depicted in the film, were stocked for such an eventuality. They contained amongst other things, at least one ruggedized [[Civil Defense Geiger counters#Type CDV-715|CDV-715]] radiation survey meter and one [[CONELRAD|CD emergency radio receiver]] which would respectively be used to facilitate a safe delayed evacuation, regardless of outside help though if communications continued, the radio receiver was to inform them of the outside situation as it developed.
== Long term survival == {{See also|Radioactive contamination#Social and psychological effects|Cobalt bomb#decontamination|Decontamination foam|Background radiation#Areas with high natural background radiation|Victory garden|Pico hydro|Wood Gas Generator|Bikini Atoll#Current habitable state}} The dubious assumption that "only the [[cockroach]]es" would survive the post-war fallout environment was frequently used in an attempt to criticize ''Duck and Cover'' during the height of the cold war, contextually at a time when discussion of a [[total war]] involved the much greater US-Soviet arsenal of nuclear weapons that were [[Megatons to Megawatts Program|then in existence]]. However even at that time, this assumption was shown to be misled, as scientifically detailed in areas including the 1988 book ''[[Philip J. Dolan#Unclassified publications|Would the Insects Inherit the Earth and Other Subjects of Concern to Those Who Worry About Nuclear War]]''.<ref>{{cite journal|url = https://journals.lww.com/health-physics/pages/articleviewer.aspx?year=1992&issue=01000&article=00004&type=abstract |title = Internal dose following a major nuclear war|journal = Health Physics|last1 = Peterson |first1 = Kendall R.|last2= Shapiro|first2= Charles S|date = January 1992|volume= 62|issue = 1|pages = 29–40|doi = 10.1097/00004032-199201000-00004|pmid = 1727410}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=https://journals.lww.com/health-physics/Abstract/1960/04000/Cobalt_60_Bombs.8.aspx|title=Cobalt-60 Bombs : Health Physics|publisher=}}</ref><ref>{{cite journal|title=Estimates of doses from global fallout|first1=André|last1=Bouville|first2=Steven L.|last2=Simon|first3=Charles W.|last3=Miller|first4=Harold L.|last4=Beck|first5=Lynn R.|last5=Anspaugh|first6=Burton G.|last6=Bennett|date=1 May 2002|journal=Health Physics|volume=82|issue=5|pages=690–705|pmid=12003019}}</ref>
In material terms, the primary life-threatening risk survivors and [[downwinders]] could face in the long-term after a nuclear explosion or war, is the "[[nuclear famine]]" issue, the potential continuation of hostilities by [[conventional warfare]] and [[radioactive contamination]] of the food and water supplies, disrupting the normal distribution and consumption, of these vital goods.
Cold-War [[continuity of government]] planners and civil defense organizations in general have always had this disruption, or "nuclear famine" issue in mind, as widespread infrastructure destruction producing starvation conditions was also seen during and after [[WWII]]. Papers such as ''On Reorganizing After Nuclear Attack'',<ref>{{cite journal|url=http://www.rand.org/pubs/papers/P3764.html|title=On Reorganizing After Nuclear Attack|date=1 January 1968|publisher=}}</ref> and ''Survival of the relocated population of the U.S. after a nuclear attack'' by Nobel Prize winner, [[Eugene Wigner]], detail the thought and attention that went into long-term survival, relocation and reconstruction.<ref>[http://web.ornl.gov/info/reports/1976/3445600218921.pdf Survival of the relocated population of the U.S. after a nuclear attack 1976. full PDF] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20170207061152/http://web.ornl.gov/info/reports/1976/3445600218921.pdf |date=2017-02-07 }}</ref>
Numerous human and agricultural [[decontamination]] countermeasures exist for the two most persistent and biologically significant isotopes,<ref>{{cite journal|url=https://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/pii/004896979390376H|title=Agricultural countermeasures following deposition of radioactivity after a nuclear accident|date=2 September 1993|journal=Science of the Total Environment|volume=137|issue=1–3|pages=31–48|via=www.sciencedirect.com|doi=10.1016/0048-9697(93)90376-H|last1=Segal|first1=M.G}}</ref><ref>{{cite journal|url=https://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/pii/004896979390391I|title=Chemical methods for reduction of the transfer of radionuclides to farm animals in semi-natural environments|date=2 September 1993|journal=Science of the Total Environment|volume=137|issue=1–3|pages=235–248|via=www.sciencedirect.com|doi=10.1016/0048-9697(93)90391-I|last1=Hove|first1=K}}</ref> [[cesium-137]], [[strontium-90]] and long-lived fallout contamination in general, with the most visible and immediate act that will prevent a potentially large dose to the public, taking the form of using shielded [[bulldozers]] to skim off the layer of [[topsoil]] that the fallout had settled on, a restorative<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.osti.gov/scitech/servlets/purl/7148724-Iw1fMC/|title=The Long-Term Problems of Contaminated Land: Sources, Impacts and Countermeasures|first=C. F. Iii|last=Baes|date=1 November 1986|publisher=|via=www.osti.gov}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www-naweb.iaea.org/nafa/faqs-food-agriculture.html|title=Joint Division Questions & Answers - Nuclear Emergency Response for Food and Agriculture, NAFA|author=Joint FAO/IAEA Programme|website=iaea.org}}</ref><ref>International Atomic Energy Agency International Atomic Enmergy Agency, 2000 - Technology & Engineering - restoration of environments with radioactive residues : papers and discussions, 697 pages</ref> practice that was fielded upon the creation of [[Lake Chagan]].<ref>{{cite av media|url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=XEqYroQEtA8|title=Born of Nuclear Blast: Russia's Lakes of Mystery|date=November 28, 2010|work=YouTube}}</ref> The creation of [[Human decontamination|human decontamination tents]] at the entrances of buildings and when lower levels of risk exist, the use of [[clean room]] [[Air shower (room)|air showers]] as a form of [[contamination control]] to prevent the spread of radionuclides that adhere to dust, into building interiors, would also be advisable to reduce the elevated risk of [[radiation induced cancer]] that would otherwise occur. Air showers may be paired with [[electrostatic precipitator]]s to attract the dust to collection plates, forestalling a re-suspension that may otherwise be inhaled.<ref>[https://ntrs.nasa.gov/archive/nasa/casi.ntrs.nasa.gov/20110015825.pdf Development of electrostatic precipitator to remove atmospheric dust]</ref><ref>[https://ntrs.nasa.gov/archive/nasa/casi.ntrs.nasa.gov/20080040790.pdf Study on removing particular contamination]</ref> Moreover use of the open access [[radioecology]] research on decontamination and conventional agriculture in the Chernobyl-[[Polesie State Radioecological Reserve]]<ref name="sciencedirect.com">{{cite journal|url=https://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/pii/S0265931X16300261|title=Thirty years after the Chernobyl accident: What lessons have we learnt?|date=1 June 2016|journal=Journal of Environmental Radioactivity|volume=157|pages=77–89|via=www.sciencedirect.com|doi=10.1016/j.jenvrad.2016.02.003|pmid=27018344|last1=Beresford|first1=N.A|last2=Fesenko|first2=S|last3=Konoplev|first3=A|last4=Skuterud|first4=L|last5=Smith|first5=J.T|last6=Voigt|first6=G}}</ref><ref>[https://books.google.ie/books?id=uElVyTd84xEC&pg=PA193&lpg=PA193&dq=giese+salt+afcf&source=bl&ots=1AtT9wFZe_&sig=8KVWaX974RhmR9avd92fmQq42Pw&hl=ga&sa=X&ved=0ahUKEwju56-al4vcAhWBIMAKHW7IAaIQ6AEIUzAJ#v=onepage&q=giese%20salt%20afcf&f=false Chernobyl: Catastrophe and Consequences By Jim Smith, Nicholas A. Beresford. 5 ''Application of countermeasures'' pg 191]</ref> and around the [[Fukushima accident]],<ref>{{cite web|url=http://fukushima.jaea.go.jp/english/decontamination/pdf/2-2-2%20Decontamination%20Technologies.pdf|title=Report on the results of the decontamination. Analysis and Evaluation of the Results of the Decontamination Model Project, decontamination technologies|publisher=}}</ref> would both be implemented in the event of any widespread fallout contamination, with particular emphasis on [[bioremediation of radionuclides]] from soil and aquifers.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20150215080519/https://news.virginia.edu/content/uva-undergraduate-researcher-studies-sunflowers-power-clean-soil|title=U.Va. The technology developed and deployed due to the [[Fukushima disaster cleanup#Water treatment|Fukushima reactor-water decontamination]] mandate,<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.tepco.co.jp/en/decommision/planaction/alps/index-e.html|title=Contaminated Water Treatment - TEPCO|website=www.tepco.co.jp}}</ref> includes the mobile [[reverse osmosis]] ''[[Landysh]]'' water treatment ship, the [[zeolite]] based "Actiflo",<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.power-eng.com/articles/npi/print/volume-6/issue-2/case-study/veolia-arevas-water-decontamination-system.html|title=Veolia & Areva's water decontamination system|website=www.power-eng.com}}</ref> the "SARRY" [[ion exchange]] cesium removal system, based on [[Jonesite|silicotitanate]] "IONSIV" crystalline rock,<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.theblaze.com/news/2012/01/09/trailer-sized-system-cleans-fukushimas-radioactive-water-and-soil-in-an-hour|title=Trailer-Sized System Cleans Fukushima's Radioactive Water and Soil in an Hour|date=9 January 2012|publisher=}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://tech.nikkeibp.co.jp/dm/english/NEWS_EN/20111223/202955/|title=Toshiba, IHI Develop Transportable Treatment System for Radiation-tainted Water|first=NIKKEI|last=XTECH|publisher=}}</ref><ref>http://www.wmsym.org/archives/2014/papers/14018.pdf</ref><ref>https://web.archive.org/web/20170813003127/http://prod.sandia.gov/techlib/access-control.cgi/1997/970771.pdf</ref><ref>{{Cite book|url=https://www.nap.edu/read/9959/chapter/7|title=Alternatives for High-Level Waste Salt Processing at the Savannah River Site|date=30 October 2000|publisher=|doi=10.17226/9959|isbn=978-0-309-07194-9|last1=Technology|first1=Board on Chemical Sciences and|last2=Management|first2=Board on Radioactive Waste|last3=Site|first3=Committee on Cesium Processing Alternatives for High-Level Waste at the Savannah River}}</ref><ref>{{cite journal|title=A Comparison of Crystalline Silicotitanate and Ammonium Molybdophosphate-Polyacrylonitrile Composite Sorbent for the Separation of Cesium from Acidic Waste|first1=T. ==Historical and psychological assessment== Some [[historian]]s and filmmakers, exemplified by the 1982 ''[[The Atomic Cafe]]'', have thus far sought to dismiss civil defense advice as mere propaganda, despite, as other historians have found, detailed scientific research programs laying behind the much-mocked government civil defense pamphlets of the 1950s and 1960s, including the prompt advice of ducking and covering.<ref name="Journals.cambridge.org"/>
In U.S. Army training, soldiers are taught to immediately fall down, covering face and hands in much the same way as is described by the advice to duck and cover.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.globalsecurity.org/wmd/library/policy/army/fm/3-4/Ch4.htm#para1 |title=field manual FM 3-4 Chapter 4. "Dropping immediately and covering exposed skin provide[s] protection against blast and thermal effects."..."Immediately drop facedown. A log, a large rock, or any depression in the earth's surface provides some protection. Close eyes. Protect exposed skin from heat by putting hands and arms under or near the body and keeping the helmet on. Remain facedown until the blast wave passes and debris stops falling. Stay calm, check for injury, check weapons and equipment damage, and prepare to continue the mission."}}</ref>
The exercises of Cold War [[civil defense]] are seen by historian Guy Oakes in 1994, as having less practical use than psychological use: to keep the danger of nuclear war high on the public mind, while also attempting to assure the American people that something could be done to defend against nuclear attack.<ref>Oakes, Guy. ''The Imaginary War: Civil Defense and Cold War Culture''. 1994, Oxford University Press. {{ISBN|0-19-509027-6}}, pp. 66–68</ref> However, according to contemporary Cold War civil defense pamphlets, like ''[[Protect and Survive|Civil Defence: Why we need it]]'' released in 1981, civil defense countermeasures were presented as analogous to [[seat belt]]s, and that the suggestion that knowing what steps to take in the "slight" possibility that a nuclear explosion occurs in your region, keeps such calamities high on the public mind, is "like saying people who wear seat belts are expecting to have more crashes than those who do not", and as with a seat belt, there is never a suggestion that if the countermeasure were implemented, it would save everyone.
Moreover, civil defense was not solely a US-UK or [[nuclear club]] phenomenon; countries with long histories of neutrality, such as [[Switzerland]], are "foremost in their civil defence precautions."<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.atomica.co.uk/cdwhy.htm |title=CIVIL DEFENCE why we need it}}</ref> The [[Military of Switzerland#Military and civil defence|Swiss civil defense]] network has an overcapacity of nuclear fallout shelters for the country's population size, and by law, new homes must still be built with a fallout shelter as of 2011.<ref>{{cite news| url=https://www.wsj.com/articles/SB10001424052702304231204576405700994655570?mod=WSJEUROPE_hpp_sections_world | work=The Wall Street Journal | first=Deborah | last=Ball | title=Swiss Renew Push for Bomb Shelters | date=2011-06-25}}</ref><ref>{{cite news| url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/programmes/from_our_own_correspondent/6347519.stm | work=BBC News | first=Imogen | last=Foulkes | title=Swiss still braced for nuclear war | date=2007-02-10}}</ref>
==Tornadoes== {{see also|Tornado drill}} [[File:Tornado drill.jpg|thumb|Students participate in a tornado drill, lining up along an interior wall and covering their heads. Tornado drills are an important element in [[tornado preparedness]]. Similar to other [[evidence based]] safety drills, they teach effective countermeasures and therefore increase survival rates if/when a tornado hits.]] Ducking and covering does have certain applications in other, more natural disasters. In states prone to [[tornado]]es, school children are urged to "duck and cover" against a solid inner wall of a school, if time does not permit seeking better shelter—such as a [[storm cellar]]—during a [[tornado warning]]. The tactic is also widely practiced in schools in states along the [[West Coast of the United States]], where [[earthquakes]] are commonplace. Ducking and covering in either scenario would theoretically afford significant protection from falling or flying debris.
==Earthquakes== {{see also|Nuclear bunker buster}} In an [[earthquake]], which are generally of a natural [[tectonic plate]] origin (although they can be artificially generated by the detonation of a nuclear explosive device in which sufficient energy is transmitted into the ground, with an extreme case to serve as an example of this phenomenon being the [[Operation Grommet]] ''[[Cannikin]]'' test of the 5 megaton [[W71]] warhead [[Underground nuclear testing|exploded deep underground]] on [[Amchitka]] Island in 1971, which produced a [[seismic shock]] quake of 7.0 on the [[Richter magnitude scale]]) people are encouraged, regardless of the cause of the quake, to "drop, cover, and hold on": to get underneath a piece of furniture, cover their heads and hold on to the furniture. This advice also encourages people not to run out of a shaking building, because a large majority of earthquake injuries are due to broken bones from people falling and tripping during shaking. While it is unlikely that "drop, cover and hold on" will protect against a building collapse, in earthquake-prone areas in the United States [[building code]]s require that buildings withstand quakes up to an expected magnitude enough to allow evacuation after shaking stops.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.livescience.com/13962-tornado-safety-building-codes.html |title=Why Aren't There Tornado Safety Building Codes?}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url=http://mceer.buffalo.edu/infoservice/Reference_Services/usCodes.asp#3 |title=Directory of Building Codes & Regulations: City & State Directory}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url=http://mceer.buffalo.edu/infoservice/Reference_Services/USInternationalCodes.asp |title=U.S. & International Seismic Codes}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.nehrp.gov/library/guidance_new.htm |title=National Earthquake Hazards Reduction Program - Comparison of U.S. and Chilean Building Code Requirements and Seismic Design Practice 1985-2010}}</ref> and thus a building collapse of these structures (even during an earthquake) is rare. "Drop, cover and hold on" may not be appropriate for all locations or building types, but the [[Red Cross]] advises<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.redcross.org/static/file_cont164_lang0_71.pdf |title=Drop, Cover, and Hold On – American Red Cross drill (pdf file) |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20060316024324/http://www.redcross.org/static/file_cont164_lang0_71.pdf |archivedate=March 16, 2006 }}</ref> it is the appropriate emergency response to an earthquake in the United States.
